definitions.example: I'm in a tight squeeze right now when it comes to my free time.

definitions.definition: A hug or other affectionate grasp.
definitions.example: a gentle squeeze on the arm
I want to be your main squeeze.

definitions.definition: An illicit alcoholic drink made by squeezing Sterno through cheesecloth, etc., and mixing the result with fruit juice.
The act of bunting in an attempt to score a runner from third.
definitions.example: The game ended in exciting fashion with a failed squeeze.

definitions.definition: A play that forces an opponent to discard a card that gives up one or more tricks.
A traversal of a narrow passage.
definitions.example: It was a tight squeeze, but I got through to the next section of the cave.

definitions.definition: (epigraphy) An impression of an inscription formed by pressing wet paper onto the surface and peeling off when dry.
definitions.example: The light not being good enough for photography, I took a squeeze of the stone.

definitions.definition: The gradual closing of workings by the weight of the overlying strata.
A bribe or fee paid to a middleman, especially in China; the practice of requiring such a bribe or fee.
To apply pressure to from two or more sides at once.
definitions.example: I squeezed the ball between my hands.

definitions.definition: To embrace closely; to give a tight hug to.
To fit into a tight place.
definitions.example: Can you squeeze through that gap?

definitions.definition: To remove something with difficulty, or apparent difficulty.
definitions.example: He squeezed some money out of his wallet.

definitions.definition: To put in a difficult position by presenting two or more choices.
definitions.example: I'm being squeezed between my job and my volunteer work.

definitions.definition: To oppress with hardships, burdens, or taxes; to harass.
To attempt to score a runner from third by bunting.
definitions.example: Jones squeezed in Smith with a perfect bunt.
